title: Edgeworth Box
description:
The Edgeworth Box is a fundamental tool in microeconomic theory for analyzing exchange between two consumers with initial endowments. This interactive model allows you to explore how equilibrium prices emerge from consumer preferences.

Equilibrium with identical Cobb-Douglas preferences: {mathFormula1} General equilibrium with different preferences: {mathFormula2}

How to use this interactive model:
  • Drag the initial endowment point to see how it affects the equilibrium
  • Adjust the preference parameters (α and β) to explore different utility functions
  • Observe how the contract curve changes with different preferences
  • The equilibrium point shows where both consumers maximize their utility given the budget constraint

title: Robinson Economy
description:
The Robinson Economy model illustrates the fundamental trade-off between leisure and consumption in a single-agent economy. This model demonstrates how an individual optimally allocates time between work and leisure to maximize utility.

Equilibrium wage-price ratio:

{mathFormula1}

Key features to explore:
  • Adjust the technology parameter (B) to see how productivity affects the equilibrium
  • Change the preference parameter (a) to explore different leisure-consumption trade-offs
  • Observe how the production possibility frontier intersects with the indifference curve
  • The tangency point represents the optimal allocation of time

title: Two Consumers and Shareholders, One Producer
description:
This advanced model combines exchange and production in a general equilibrium framework. Two consumers with different preferences interact with a producer, creating a rich economic environment.

Equilibrium prices:
{mathFormula1}

Wage-price ratio with production:
{mathFormula2}

Interactive elements:
  • Adjust consumer preferences (a, b) to see how demand affects equilibrium
  • Click on 'Switch Prod. on' to add production to the model
  • Change the production technology parameter (λ) to explore different returns to scale
  • Modify initial endowments to understand wealth effects
  • Observe how the producer's profit maximization interacts with consumer utility maximization

title: UMP Exercise 1: Cobb-Douglas
description:
Solve the Utility Maximization Problem with Cobb-Douglas preferences. This exercise demonstrates the fundamental consumer choice problem.

Problem setup:
Maximize \(U(x,y) = x^a y^{1-a}\) subject to \(p_x x + p_y y = I\)

Solution:
\(x^* = \frac{a \cdot I}{p_x}\) and \(y^* = \frac{(1-a) \cdot I}{p_y}\)

Instructions:
  • Adjust the preference parameter α to see how it affects the optimal bundle
  • Change prices to observe substitution and income effects
  • Modify the budget to explore how wealth changes consumption

title: UMP Exercise 2: Corner Solution
description:
Explore corner solutions in utility maximization when the marginal rate of substitution exceeds the price ratio at the boundaries.

Problem setup:
When preferences are such that \(MRS > \frac{p_x}{p_y}\) even at extreme consumption bundles, the consumer specializes in one good.

Corner solution conditions:
{mathFormula1}

Key concepts:
  • Observe when interior solutions fail to exist
  • Understand boundary behavior of indifference curves
  • Explore cases with perfect substitutes or strong preferences
  • See how price ratios determine which corner is optimal

title: UMP Exercise 3: Perfect Complements
description:
Analyze utility maximization with Leontief (perfect complements) preferences, where goods must be consumed in fixed proportions.

Utility function:
{mathFormula1}

Optimal consumption bundle:
{mathFormula2}

Features to explore:
  • L-shaped indifference curves representing fixed consumption ratios
  • The optimal bundle always lies at the 'kink' of the indifference curve
  • Price changes lead to pure income effects (no substitution)
  • Adjust the complementarity ratio a/b to see different optimal proportions

mathFormulas: \[ \Large \min_{x,y} \: p_x x + p_y y \quad \text{s.t.} \quad x^a y^{1-a} \geq \bar{U} \]
title: EMP Exercise 1: Cobb-Douglas
description:
Solve the Expenditure Minimization Problem with Cobb-Douglas preferences. Find the cheapest way to achieve a given utility level.

Problem formulation:
{mathFormula1}

Cost-minimizing ratio:
{mathFormula2}

Interactive elements:
  • Set the target utility level \(\bar{U}\) and observe the minimum cost
  • Change prices to see how the optimal bundle adjusts
  • Compare with the dual UMP problem
  • Explore the expenditure function \(e(p_x, p_y, \bar{U})\)

title: UMP Exercise 5: CES Utility
description:
Explore the Constant Elasticity of Substitution (CES) utility function, a flexible form that nests multiple preference types.

CES utility function:
{mathFormula1}

Elasticity of substitution:
{mathFormula2}

Optimal consumption ratio:
{mathFormula3}

Special cases to explore:
  • ρ → 1: Perfect substitutes (σ → ∞)
  • ρ → 0: Cobb-Douglas (σ = 1)
  • ρ → -∞: Perfect complements (σ → 0)
  • Adjust ρ to see how substitutability affects optimal choices

mathFormulas: \[ \Large h(p_x, p_y, \bar{U}) = \arg\min_{x,y} \{p_x x + p_y y : (ax^\rho + by^\rho)^{1/\rho} \geq \bar{U}\} \]
title: EMP Exercise 6: CES Expenditure
description:
Solve the Expenditure Minimization Problem with CES preferences, exploring how the elasticity of substitution affects cost-minimizing behavior.

Hicksian demand:
{mathFormula1}

Expenditure function:
{mathFormula2}

Interactive analysis:
  • Vary the elasticity parameter to see how it affects expenditure
  • Compare expenditure functions across different utility specifications
  • Observe how Hicksian demands respond to price changes
  • Explore the duality between UMP and EMP in the CES framework

title: Probability Distributions
description:
Explore 24 of the most common probability distributions used in statistics. This interactive visualization allows you to understand the shape, parameters, and properties of each distribution.

Example - Normal Distribution: {mathFormula1}
Example - Exponential Distribution: {mathFormula2}

Features:
  • Toggle between continuous and discrete distributions
  • Adjust parameters in real-time to see how they affect the distribution shape
  • Compare multiple distributions simultaneously
  • View probability density/mass functions and cumulative distribution functions
  • Explore special cases and limiting behaviors

title: Newton's Method
description:
Visualize the iterative process of Newton's Method for finding roots of functions. This powerful numerical method uses tangent line approximations to converge to solutions.

Iteration formula: {mathFormula1}

How to use:
  • Enter any function f(x) to find its roots
  • Click on the graph to set the initial guess x₀
  • Watch the algorithm converge step by step
  • Observe how the choice of initial point affects convergence
  • Explore cases where the method fails to converge

title: Taylor Series
description:
Explore how functions can be approximated by polynomial series. This interactive tool demonstrates the power of Taylor series in approximating complex functions.

Taylor series formula: {mathFormula1}

Interactive features:
  • Choose from common functions (sin, cos, exp, log, etc.)
  • Adjust the center point 'a' for the expansion
  • Control the number of terms in the approximation
  • See the error between the function and its Taylor approximation
  • Explore the radius of convergence visually

title: Linear Regression, 2D
description:
Understand the fundamentals of linear regression in two dimensions. This interactive model helps visualize the least squares method and regression diagnostics.

Regression model: {mathFormula1}
Slope estimator: {mathFormula2}

Features:
  • (in progress...)

title: Linear Regression, 3D
description:
Extend your understanding of regression to three dimensions. This visualization shows how a plane fits through data points in 3D space.

Multiple regression model: {mathFormula1}

Interactive elements:
  • Rotate the 3D view to understand the regression plane
  • Add data points in three-dimensional space
  • Observe how the plane adjusts to minimize squared residuals
  • Explore the geometric interpretation of multiple regression
  • Understand partial effects by holding one variable constant
